thread.title: When is the new pound coin out in 2017? All you need to know about the 12-sided £1 coin launch
thread.title_full: When is the new pound coin out in 2017? All you need to know about the 12-sided £1 coin launch

author: Emma Munbodh
title: When is the new pound coin out in 2017? All you need to know about the 12-sided £1 coin launch
text:
1p coin sells for £72,000 at auction What will happen after 15 October? 
Many banks and building societies will continue to accept the old pound coin even after 15 October, although Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds/Bank of Scotland, Nationwide, RBS and Santander have said they will only offer this service for their own customers. 
After 15 October, you'll still be able to deposit round £1 coins into your bank account, however, this is at the discretion of your local bank so it is recommended that you consult with them directly. 
Some of the round £1 coins returned by the public will be melted down and reused to make the new £1 coin. What does the new coin look like? The coins are being made at 4,000 a minute at a Royal Mint production office in Llantrisant, Wales (Photo: PA) 
The new coin is made of two metals, with a gold-coloured outer ring and a silver-coloured inner ring. 
It has an image that changes from a "£" symbol to the number "1" when the coin is seen from different angles. It also has very small lettering on both sides of the coin and milled edges. 
It is thinner and lighter than the round pound, but its diameter is slightly larger. Read More Are there any collectibles I should watch for? The answer could be yes (Photo: Royal Mint/PA) 
The new pound coins are yet to launch, but a number of them are already selling on eBay.co.uk for as much as £200. 
More than 200,000 of the brand new coins have been spotted on the online auction website, after being handed out to selected retailers last year for "testing". 
The new coins are considered "trial coins", and therefore aren't rare, or legitimate legal tender. They cannot be used in shops, and in March will not become official tender. Read More New £1 coins ALREADY selling for hundreds on eBay - and they're not even out in the UK yet 
However, they're already selling for a profit online, and experts are predicting their value to go up even further when the official coin is released in spring. 
Lucky holder "Glanvog" sold his edition for £200 last month, after eBay.co.uk bidders ramped up the war for the sought after coin. (Photo: eBay.co.uk) 
Speaking to Mirror Money, Alex Cassidy, from GoCompare's Coining It In platform, described the bids as "fascinating" and reminiscent of the 1994 trial £2 coin that has come to "become one of the most sought after collectable coins in Britain". 
"These new £1 trial coins are fascinating, especially considering the financial precedent of the £2.00 trial coins in 1994, which have since become one of the most sought after collectable coins in Britain," he said. 
"The fact that people are already trying to sell them on eBay shows just how coin-mad the general public have become in the last few years. 
"After all, if these new trial coins turn out to be as valuable as 1994’s, then anyone who gets their hands on them now could be sitting on a future goldmine." Read More The most valuable £1 and £2 coins - have you got any stashed away? 
Twenty five different designs have appeared on the current round pound coin, from dragons to trees, many of which are now selling online. 
Royal Mint chief executive Adam Lawrence said there are also plans strike a billion of the new coins, which are made from two types of metal, before its launch in March. 
It will feature the national flora of the UK’s four countries emerging from a coronet. 
Dr Kevin Clancy, director of the Royal Mint Museum, said: “This year we also mark the achievements of Jane Austen, Sir Isaac Newton and The Royal Flying Corps – all pioneers in their own field. 
"The British public should start to see these coins appearing in their change from spring 2017." Read More
